item.title: Announced: IH/IF/IP/2025: Summary, Sights, and Sample Content
item.description:
“An Illustrated Overview of the 2-Day Event”

Here is the breakdown of the 16 sessions of the inaugural In-house In-focus In-person that took place this past March 27 – 28 in Dallas, TX, and which was awesome. (If you are looking at this in an RSS reader head on over to the real thing, too much heavy formatting). This is a very long post with a photo of each speaker, a highlight of their presentation, and some sample slides from their deck, so give it a good time to load. A few other things worth bullet-pointing:

  • Unlike the Brand New Conference, videos can not be purchased so if you like what you see below, consider registering for the 2026 edition!
  • A lot more photos from the event have been posted in this Flickr album.
  • Samples of the program, tote bag, and t-shirt are available for purchase.
  • Registration is now open for In-house In-focus In-person In 2026 in Chicago, IL, on March 19 – 20 at Harris Theater at Millennium Park.

All event photos by Sofia Negron. (On the grid images below you can click to open a bigger version.)

In-house In-focus In-person In 2026 is scheduled for March 19 – 20 at Harris Theater at Millennium Park. Pre-sale registration available now. See you there?

item.title: Linked: From the Room Where it Happened
item.description:
Visit Link

Lin-Manuel Miranda shares the nine posters designed by SpotCo that were considered for his genre-busting show Hamilton before they settled on the now iconic star and Alexander silhouette graphic (center in the image above) that has appeared in productions all over the world.

item.title: Noted: New Logo and Packaging for Rollr by Mother Design
item.description:
“Roll Model”

(Est. 2024) “Designed for pleasure and planet, Rollr is the refillable roll-on deodorant with natural and effective zero-waste refills. Feeling good never felt so good. An innovative and sustainable new approach it offers a refillable roll-on for the first time, it also brings a no-nonsense, sophisticated cool aesthetic. These deodorants use a patent-pending, non-leak cradle and frictionless refillable rolling mechanism, with a choice of medical grade stainless steel or a unique gemstone Rollr ball in Rose Quartz, Green Aventurine or Blue Dumortierite, each said to have additional wellness benefits from healing and harmony to mental clarity and focus.”

Design by
Mother Design

Related links
Mother Design press release

Relevant quote
Mother Design’s category audits showed that the natural deodorant market has often relied on outdated sustainability cues, with products that felt primarily functional. No brands were leaning into pleasure, despite the growing demand for sensorial and mind-body stimulation in beauty and personal care. As sustainability increasingly becomes a hygiene factor, Rollr taps into the shift towards products that balance responsibility and indulgence, with a product that can be proudly displayed alongside treasured fragrances rather than banished to the bathroom cabinet.

As well as the visual identity Mother Design co-created Rollr’s distinctive bottle design with founder, Pinckney and product designer, Joshua Oates, to create something that moves beyond the functional and disposable aesthetic of typical deodorants. Inspired by fine fragrance design, the smooth, sculpted glass bottle is intended to be a permanent object, kept and refilled indefinitely. A modular and patented screw-top neck allows for easy refilling, reinforcing Rollr’s commitment to sustainability. Unlike plastic roll-ons, Rollr features a cooling steel roller ball, with optional gemstone upgrades—Rose Quartz, Green Aventurine, and Blue Dumortierite—that enhance the sensory experience with a gentle massage to one of your body’s most sensitive areas. The darkened glass bottle is complemented by light pastel tones, reflecting the natural ingredients of each scent, including mandarin, vetiver, and clary sage.

The name ‘Rollr’, inspired by the product’s roller ball feature, is the only familiar aspect of the product, ensuring instant recognition amidst an otherwise unexpected reinvention of the category. The word 'roller' was chosen to immediately communicate function, helping users understand its purpose before discovering how every other aspect challenges expectations. Removing the 'e' gives it a modern, distinctive edge—maintaining familiarity while signalling a modern, distinctive edge that is both memorable and easily searchable.

The brand’s tone of voice reflects the mindset of a ‘conscientious hedonist’ - a persona developed by Mother Design to describe someone who embraces pleasure while being mindful of environmental impact. The brand voice is bold and expressive, featuring phrases such as “Damn you smell good” and “For pleasure and planet.”

The logo is a custom-drawn wordmark with elegant serifs and a liquid-like curve extending from the bowl to the leg of the ‘R’, echoing the cooling, fluid nature of the product. The counter of the ‘o’ is rotated to suggest a rolling motion. The clean and modern Kalice typeface is used throughout the brand, providing a refined yet understated contrast to the more expressive elements.

Images (opinion after)

Opinion
As a lifelong user of Speed Stick, the one category I was least expecting to go full fashion and high class was deodorants but here we are. The premise of the product is kind of intriguing, with a slick roller ball (called a “gemstone” in this brand world) helping dispense the odor- and sweat-quenching formula living on a reusable, elegant glass container. It's luxurious and, at least on the surface, eco-conscious by not being another disposable plastic container. To match the premise, a curvy, swervy, elegant wordmark in a high-contrast serif has been customized with an “R” that literally looks as if it's rolling along its contour. In principle, this should be an easy home run or at the very least a base hit but the thicknesses on what should be equally thin parts of the letters are all over the place. Not one is equal to another. The pinch of the “R” should be the same as where the axis hits the “o”, which should be the same as the extension of the arm in the “r”, which in turn should match the top of the “R”, which furthermore has thicker serifs on the top and bottom than any of the other letters. If that sentence was hard to read or follow: good, because that's how much sense the construction of this logo makes. It pains me to be so harsh on this logo because it could have easily been so good. While the bottle itself is lovely, the brief glimpses at the actual packaging around it is not the most enticing, feeling a little underwhelming and unfinished. The additional squiggles for each of the scents are somewhat interesting and a nice play on the name but they, once more, add yet another range of thick-and-thin contrasts that don't match the logo. The supporting typography, using Kalice, feels loosely implemented and somewhat random in its use of Roman vs. Italics. The burgundy color is nice, though. The few other applications shown are fine and mostly benefit from the product photography that showcases the bottle as there isn't much else to it. Overall, despite an initial strong first impression I was surprised at how many things I found to be unresolved and inconsistent across product, logo, packaging, and photography but I am assuming the novelty of Rollr will be enough to make it a covetable item.

item.title: Reviewed: New Logo and Identity for BMG by Wolff Olins
item.description:
“Power Play”

Established in 2008, BMG is the fourth-largest music company in the world — behind the big three of Universal Music Group, Sony Music Entertainment, and Warner Music Group — representing more than three million songs and recordings, including iconic catalogs and works from leading artists and songwriters like The Rolling Stones, Tina Turner, Iron Maiden, Mötley Crüe, Blondie, and more as well as contemporary artists like Kylie Minogue, Lenny Kravitz, and Jelly Roll, among many others. With 20 offices across 13 key markets and as a wholly owned and privately held subsidiary of Bertelsmann, one of Europe’s largest media companies, BMG combines the activities of a music publisher and a record label and prides itself on “offering fairer contracts, greater creative freedom, and unparalleled transparency in royalties and licensing”. Recently, BMG introduced a new identity designed by Wolff Olins.

To help shape BMG’s brand, we built on its strengths as a business and client partner: its trailblazing DNA, unique long-term outlook, global integration and collaborative ethos. Centring on a north star of ‘grow boldly together,’ we collaborated with its team to evolve its identity to express its dynamic, creator-centric spirit, starting with a new symbol to complement the stability of its existing wordmark. The symbol was inspired by the idea of play, forward momentum, and BMG’s connected ecosystem, informing a wider graphic system of patterns and icons that evoke music and add energy, joy, and movement to the new visual identity.

Wolff Olins project page

Colour plays a starring role in the new identity, anchored by new hero colours like the vibrant “Limelight,” sophisticated “Midnight” and metallic-inspired neutrals. The core corporate palette is supported by a dynamic set of secondary colours that celebrate the full spectrum of music and spotlight the creativity of those represented by BMG. Together, the colours embody a balance of heritage and innovation, stability and playfulness, intellect, and emotion. The colour palette is rounded out by additional tools—like graphic elements and patterns inspired by the symbol as well as a dynamic voice—to create a spectrum of moments that feel like BMG.

Wolff Olins project page

Remaining in play (no further pun intended), the old logo is a half-decent wordmark with a cool “G”, a decent “B”, and an unfortunate mismatched “M” (or “m”) that looks oddly out of place — seems like it would have been so easy to replicate the more squared-off rounded corners of the “G” and I’m kind of bummed the update didn’t address it but I am guessing the mandate was to keep their hands off of it. Now, as a supporting element to the more effusive and attention-grabbing icon, the wordmark is, as a whole, at odds with the icon given that the two elements are each beating to their own drum. It’s not heavily dissonant to be fair but had the wordmark been allowed to change, there could be better ways to find some synergy between the two.

Having said that, the new icon is actually pretty great on its own, with a highly satisfying geometric construction where all of the triangles snap to each other to form a circle made of concentric rings. Part of what makes it great is the variation in the thickness of each ring and the amount of triangles within which yields a highly textural and almost organic design but with a groovy kaleidoscopic precision to it. In animation, the rings all animate at different speeds for a cool combination-lock effect while maintaining the central triangle static and reinforcing the “play” concept.

As a big fan of patterns and geometric precision, the above videos are endlessly satisfying to me and I could watch them all day. Aside from literally emanating from the icon, I’m not sure of their conceptual relevance to the music industry but perhaps there isn’t a need for there to be one and sometimes you just have to go with the flow — and this flows.

The identity then turns to Graphik as the primary typeface and, at first, it is used straight-up and demurely to present some solid copywriting but is then stretched and squeezed vertically and horizontally in fairly dramatic proportions when presenting artists. I used to be quite graphically triggered ages ago by this kind of typographic treatment but I have learned to let go of that anger and appreciate the uncommon, awkward, sometimes fun proportions that the effect yields, which are soothed in this case by some slick motion behaviors and, somehow, Graphik manages to keep its cool regardless of how it’s treated.

Overall, as the patterns and stretched type all come together in some funky static and motion compositions, the identity, one way or another, does find a novel and interesting way to convey the energy and diversity of the music the company represents while also maintaining a certain corporate-ness to it all.

item.title: Linked: To Each Hiss Own
item.description:
Visit Link

Unilever-owned deodorant brand, Lynx, has created a fragrance that mixes 50% catnip oil with geranium, nutmeg, and cedar so that suitors can win over both their object of desire AND the latter’s feline companion. This solves an apparent issue revealed through a survey that found that 60% of cat owners wouldn’t date someone their cat dislikes. It looks like an April Fools, it smells like an April Fools, but given that it was posted before April 1, it seems legit.

item.title: Noted: New Logo and Identity for Veikkausliiga by Bond
item.description:
“Scarf Ace”

(Est. 1990) “Veikkausliiga is the top professional football league in Finland and the highest tier of the Finnish football league system, consisting of the country’s 12 best clubs. As one of the northernmost football leagues in the world, Veikkausliiga follows a spring-to-autumn season, typical for cold-climate European leagues. The league format ensures that every match counts: after 22 rounds (each team playing against every other team twice), the bottom six clubs compete in a single relegation round, while the top six advance to a double championship round. Interest in Veikkausliiga and Finnish football has been on the rise, particularly since the Finland national team qualified for its first-ever major tournament, UEFA Euro 2020 (postponed to 2021). The excitement is set to grow even further with the return of Teemu Pukki – Finland’s all-time leading male goalscorer – to Veikkausliiga for the upcoming season, following more than a decade in Europe’s top leagues and Major League Soccer in the United States.”

Design by
Bond

Related links
Bond project page
Veikkausliiga blog post

Relevant quote
At the heart of the new identity is the modernised version of Veikkausliiga’s iconic symbol - a fan holding a scarf aloft. Recognising that football is more than just a game, it is something you feel, the whole brand embraces this age-old idea of the fan and their scarf. A celebration of genuine emotions, reinforcing the league’s commitment to both long-time and new supporters, BOND has crafted a brand that captures the unity, excitement, and pride of supporting your local club – best experienced at the stadium.

Further building on the brand’s signature visual element, a custom typeface - Scarf Gothic - was created, reflecting the folds and movement of a supporter’s scarf. This design choice seamlessly integrates emotion into the brand’s core aesthetic.

Images (opinion after)

Opinion
While a more “normal” version of the old logo exists, it was the one shown above that was most recently used on the league's website and it was quite a feat of Photoshop engineering resulting in a painfully dated look that turned an already awkward and highly detailed icon into something way more (and unnecessarily) complicated. The typography within it was also kind of terrible, looking like a bad auto trace of some variation of FF Cocon Condensed, which, *shivers*. But that's enough roasting of the old logo. The new logo is a deep abstraction of the player/fan holding a scarf over their head and, as someone that had not seen the old logo before seeing the new logo, I will admit I was very unclear what the new icon was meant to be but I imagine that will not be a problem with Finnish fans who have been accustomed to the old graphic for nearly 25 years. Even then, the abstraction is taken perhaps too far and, with the straightened scarf lines above the head and arms, it just starts to look like an odd geometric composition with no head or tails to discern. I do like the flexibility of the new scarf motif to change colors and adapt to each team. The icon is matched with the identity's main attraction, which is a custom typeface constructed from folded scarves. It's actually a pretty amazing typeface for being based on such a specific concept, as it yields a very unique visual style that instantly establishes a unique and distinct style for the league. The flex that the characters can literally be rendered in real folded scarves is such a fun twist and its two-color variations that also adapt to the various teams is yet another excellent adaptation. Unfortunately, the typeface sort of stands on its own… meaning, it clashes heavily with the icon in the logo as well as with the series of patterns that are operating on a whole other visual language. The photography is all over the place too… it's black and white, it's full color, it's duotone, it's silhouetted, it's not, etc. In the one or two instances where it appears, the supporting type is quite flat and the icon feels like it's just floating. Overall, this had an excellent anchor in the custom typeface but the rest of the elements don't quite add up or mix well despite a valiant attempt at infusing this identity with energy and arming the league with a flexible toolkit.
